text.38: No one will bear the burden of another. Every person who commits a sin due to their disbelief or disobedience, then they alone will bear the burden of their sin, and it will not be borne by another. And if one heavily burdened with sin calls (upon another) to bear his burden, not a bit of it will be carried, even if he is a close relative. (Fathir/35: 18)
text.39:
Regarding good deeds, a person only obtains rewards from their own efforts, and they are not entitled to the reward for an action they did not perform. From this verse, Imam Malik and Imam Shafi'i understand that it is not permissible to gift the reward of a living person's deeds, such as reciting the Qur'an, to the deceased, because it is not their action or their effort. Likewise, all physical acts of worship, such as prayer, Hajj, and recitation, because the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) never mentioned such a thing to the ummah, never commanded it indirectly or through explicit texts, nor did the Companions convey it to us. If such an action were good, they would have done it first. As for charity (sadaqah), its reward reaches the deceased, as narrated by Muslim and al-Bukhari from Abu Hurairah, that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "When a son of Adam dies, all his deeds come to an end except for three: a righteous child who prays for him, ongoing charity (waqf) after him, and knowledge from which benefit is derived." (Narrated by Muslim from Abu Hurairah)

In reality, all of this is included in a person's own effort and labor, as mentioned in the hadith:

"Indeed, the best thing a person eats is from the result of his own labor, and his child is also part of his labor." (Narrated by an-Nasa'i and Ibn Hibban) Ongoing charity, such as waqf, is a trace of his effort. Allah says:

"Indeed, it is We who bring the dead to life and record what they have put forth and what they left behind, and all things We have enumerated in a clear register." (Yasin/36: 12)

Knowledge that is spread and then people follow it and practice it is also included in his effort. And it has been narrated, among them a sahih hadith: "Whoever calls to guidance will have a reward similar to the reward of those who follow him, without diminishing their reward in the slightest." (Narrated by Muslim)

Imam Ahmad bin Hanbal and the majority of the followers of Shafi'i are of the opinion that the reward of recitation reaches the deceased if the recitation is not paid for with wages. But if the recitation is done for wages, as usually happens now, then the reward does not reach the deceased, because it is haram to take wages for reciting the Qur'an, although it is permissible to take wages for teaching it. Included among the acts of worship whose reward reaches others are prayer (du'a) and charity (sadaqah).
text.40: A person's deeds will be shown on the Day of Gathering (Mahsyar) so that everyone will be able to see them. This means honor for the good people and humiliation for the evil people. And say, "Work [righteous deeds], and Allah will see your work, and [so will] His Messenger and the believers. And you will be returned to the Knower of the unseen and the witnessed, and He will inform you of what you used to do." (at-Taubah/9: 105)
text.41:
This verse states that Allah will recompense a person's deeds with a more perfect reward by multiplying their good deeds for them, and recompensing an evil deed with its like or forgiving it.

Inform My servants that I am the Forgiving, the Merciful, and that My punishment is indeed a most painful punishment. (al-Hijr/15: 49-50)
text.42:
Allah is the place of return for all things on the Day of Resurrection, and He will reckon the small and the great, then He will reward or punish according to their respective deeds. This verse is a stern warning for the wicked, and a subtle encouragement for the righteous, and as a comfort to the heart of the Prophet Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, as His saying:

So let not their speech grieve you, [O Muhammad]. Indeed, We know what they conceal and what they declare. (Yasin/36:76)
text.43: It is Allah who makes [people] laugh and weep, along with the causes thereof. Meaning, He is the One who makes people happy because of their good deeds, and He is the One who causes people to be sad, weep, and be concerned because of their deeds, namely deeds that are pleasing or distressing.
text.44: In this verse, Allah affirms that indeed He is the One who creates death and life because He is the Being capable of giving life, causing death, and resurrecting. He who created death and life, in order to test you, which of you is best in deed. And He is the Almighty, the Forgiving. (al-Mulk/67: 2)
text.45: Allah created male and female from "semen emitted into the womb." Then He breathed the spirit into it, so it lives and moves. Verse 45 further explains the pairing of creation. The explanation can be seen in several previous verses, such as: Yasin/36: 36; ar-Ra'd/13: 3; asy-Syu'ara'/26: 7; and adh-Dhariyat/51: 49. Verse 46 explains the creation of humans that comes from male and female pairs, as stated in several previous verses. Semen as one of the components forming life is described only briefly. The explanation can be found in several descriptions in verses, such as, al-Hajj/22: 5; al-Mu'minun/23: 13-14; and Fathir/35: 11. In these verses, the stages in the process of human embryo development have been described in great detail. Even regarding semen itself, it is explained, among other things, in the verses as-Sajdah/32: 7-9. text.47: Allah is the One who resurrects mankind after death to recompense those who do good or evil according to what they did.
text.48:
Allah grants wealth or poverty to whomever He wills among His servants, according to their respective abilities and efforts. This verse demonstrates perfect power, that the *nuthfah* (a drop of semen) is according to its parts in reality. From this *nuthfah*, Allah creates various limbs, different natures, and male or female, so no one can claim to create it, just as no one claims to create the heavens and the earth except Allah.

And indeed, if you (Muhammad) ask them, "Who created the heavens and the earth?" They will surely say, "Allah." (Luqman/31: 25)

Does man think that he will be left neglected (without accountability)? Was he not initially a drop of semen emitted (into the womb), then (the semen) became something clinging, then Allah created and proportioned [him], and made of him two sexes, male and female. Is not that [Creator] able to give life to the dead? (al-Qiyamah/75: 36-40)
text.49: In this verse, Allah states that He is the Lord who possesses the star Sirius, this very brilliant star, which rises in conjunction with the star Gemini in the middle of summer. Singling out this star from other, larger and more brilliant celestial bodies is because this star was worshipped in the pre-Islamic era (jahiliyah), worshipped by the tribes of Himyar and Khuza'ah. The first person to institute this worship was Abu Kabsyah. He was a prominent figure among the Arabs, so the Quraysh declared that the Prophet Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him (saw), was the son of Abu Kabsyah, as a comparison because he differed in his religious principles from the religion of their ancestors. This Abu Kabsyah was one of the Prophet Muhammad's ancestors from his mother's side. As Abu Sufyan said when he was in the presence of Heraclius, the Emperor of Rome, "Indeed, the affair of the son of Abu Kabsyah (the Prophet saw) has become great." Among the Arabs, there were those who worshipped stars and acknowledged their influence on the universe, and they spoke about matters of the unseen when that star rose. There are two Sirius stars, one of which is located in the direction of Syam (Palestine) and the other is located in the direction of Yemen. This explanation is what is meant here, that it was worshipped besides Allah.
text.50:
Allah destroyed the first 'Ad people, who were the people of Prophet Hud, and the second 'Ad people were the people of Iram bin Sam bin Nuh.

Have you not considered how your Lord dealt with 'Ad - (the people of) Iram - who had lofty pillars, the likes of which had never been created in the lands? (al-Fajr/89: 6-8)

This second 'Ad people were a group of people who were very strong and committed many acts of disobedience to Allah and His Messenger. Then Allah destroyed them with a very cold and strong wind. Allah inflicted that wind upon them for seven nights and seven days continuously.
text.51:
Allah destroyed the Thamud people and did not allow them to live. Indeed, they were punished with the most severe torment of their Lord. In a verse with a similar meaning, Allah says:

So do you see any of them remaining? (al-Haqqah/69: 8)
text.52:
Allah destroyed the people of Noah before the people of 'Ad and Thamud. They were more unjust than these two peoples, because they were the first to commit injustice and disobedience, and the most unjust person, as in the Prophet's hadith, "Whoever initiates an evil deed, then he bears its sin." The people of Noah were more disobedient than the people of 'Ad and Thamud, because they had transgressed, even though they had long heard the call of the Prophet Noah, but they remained defiant until the Prophet Noah ran out of patience and prayed for their destruction.

And Noah said, "My Lord, do not leave upon the earth from among the disbelievers an inhabitant. (Nuh/71:26)

There was a father who took his son to Noah to warn him, saying to his son, "O my son! My father used to bring me to this man, just as I am bringing you now. Beware, do not believe him!" The father died in his disbelief, while his young son lived adhering to his father's will, so that Noah's call to teach people to believe no longer affected the child.
text.53:
Allah destroyed the people of Lot by overturning their land and sending down upon them a punishment in the form of a rain of burning stones, pelting them with stones of baked clay, one after another. In another verse with a similar meaning, Allah says:

"And We rained upon them a rain (of stones), and evil was the rain of those who had been warned." (ash-Shu'ara'/26: 173)

This is what Allah intends by His saying, "So there covered them that which covered them." The expression of the situation with those words indicates the severity of the punishment that befell them because Allah overturned it, the top becoming the bottom and the bottom becoming the top. This clear and obvious explanation could not convince them; instead, it made them doubt, and they laughed at it, even though the Prophet Muhammad (saw) continuously warned them. In reality, they should have wept over their mistakes and negligence and prostrated to Allah.

text.55:
Allah states in the form of a question to mankind about which of His blessings are still doubted, in the following verse which has the same meaning.

"O mankind! What has deceived you concerning your Lord, the Most Generous?" (al-Infithar/82: 6)

"But man is ever more contentious." (al-Kahf/18: 54)

"So which of the favors of your Lord would you deny?" (ar-Rahman/55: 16) In essence, the calamities that befall can bring people to awareness for those who pay attention. All these blessings are clear evidence of the Oneness of Allah.
text.56:
This verse states that indeed the Prophet Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, with the Quran, is a warner against those who deviate from His guidance by following their desires, which lead to misfortune in this world and the hereafter. The Prophet Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, like the previous messengers, conveyed the call to humanity, but some people denied his prophethood. Therefore, Allah destroyed and inflicted punishment upon them in accordance with their denial and rejection of the blessings that continuously came from the Lord, as stated in another verse:

"He is only a warner to you before a severe punishment." (Saba'/34: 46)

In a hadith of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, related to this verse: "I am a naked warner." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim) The meaning is, due to the urgency of seeing the evil, he did not even have time to put on clothes, and immediately set out to warn his people. It could also mean plain and firm.
text.57:
This verse explains that the Day of Judgment is near and Hell has been prepared. Every human will receive recompense according to their deeds, so be vigilant, lest you be among those who perish, that is, on a day that is of no use. At that time, neither wealth nor children will avail, except for those who come before Allah with a pure heart on the day when one family member cannot benefit another in the slightest, and they will receive no help whatsoever.

When the Day of Judgment occurs, its occurrence cannot be denied (refuted). (al-Waqi'ah/56: 1-2) And it is mentioned in a hadith: "My prophethood compared to the Day of Judgment is like these two," and he separated his middle and index fingers. (Narrated by Ahmad)
text.58: This verse explains that no one knows the time of the Day of Judgment except Allah. Therefore, prepare to face that day before it comes suddenly, in a state where you do not expect it. You will regret mistakes that are of no use, so do good deeds while there is still an opportunity to do so. This verse reveals three kinds of religious foundations: 1. The Oneness of Allah, based on His word; "Then which of the favors of your Lord will you doubt?" 2. The confirmation of the prophethood of Prophet Muhammad (saw), with His word; "This (Muhammad) is a warner." 3. The confirmation of the gathering and resurrection on the Day of Judgment with His word; "The Approaching Day has drawn near."
text.59:
This verse is revealed in the form of a question, meaning: Is it fitting for you, after this clear explanation, that people are amazed by the Qur'an, while the Qur'an brings guidance for you to the right path and leads you to the straight path; or do you still look down on it by mocking and turning away from it? Al-Baihaqi in the book *Syu'abul Iman* narrates from Abu Hurairah, who said, "When Allah's word was revealed, 'Then do you wonder at this statement?' (An-Najm/53:59), the *Ahli Suffah* wept until their tears flowed down their cheeks. And when the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) saw their tears, he also wept, and then we wept because of his tears, saying: Those who weep out of fear of Allah will not enter hell, and those who continuously commit sins will not enter paradise. And if people did not commit sins, Allah would surely bring people who sin, then they would ask for forgiveness, and Allah would forgive them. (Narrated by al-Baihaqi)

Then Allah states the obligation to glorify and be humble when hearing the Qur'an, as Allah says:

And they fall upon their faces weeping, and it increases them in humility. (al-Isra'/17: 109)
